questions.text: Mitochondrial sheaths are found in which part of the sperm?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Middle piece Middle piece: It contains the axial filament in the center that is surrounded by spirally arranged mitochondrial sheath.

Highyeild:

The tail consists of three parts: middle piece, principal piece, and end piece. Middle piece: It contains the axial filament in the center that is surrounded by spirally arranged mitochondrial sheath. At the distal end of the middle piece there is a ring-like structure through which axial filament passes. It is called annulus and is derived from the other centriole. Principal piece: It is made of axial filament covered by seven outer dense fibers. End piece: It is made up of only the axial filament.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Tail The tail of sperm consists of three parts: middle piece, principal piece, and end piece and middle piece contains the axial filament in the center that is surrounded by spirally arranged mitochondrial sheath. Option: C. Principal piece Principal piece of the sperm tail is made of axial filament covered by seven outer dense fibers. Option: D. Connecting piece The connecting piece is made up of a pair of centrioles in the cytoplasm of round spermatids.

Table:

#MANTRA Spermatid (round cell) Spermatozoon (elongated cell) Nucleus Head Golgi apparatus Acrosomal cap One centrosome Two centrioles ● One lies in the neck and forms axial filament ● Other forms annulus at the distal end of middle piece Mitochondria ● Spirally surround the axial filament between the neck and annulus to form the middle piece; the remaining axial filament forms the tail Cell membrane Cell membrane

questions.text: In which stage of meiosis is the primary oocyte arrested?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diplotene Primary oocytes are arrested in the diplotene stage of prophase I of meiosis I. This arrest occurs during fetal development and lasts until a female reaches puberty.

Highyeild:

Stage What happens Fetal development Oogonia differentiate into primary oocytes and enter meiosis Puberty Arrested primary oocytes resume meiosis I and produce a secondary oocyte and a first polar body Ovulation The secondary oocyte is released from the ovary and is in metaphase II of meiosis II Fertilization If fertilization occurs, the secondary oocyte completes meiosis II to produce a mature ovum

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Leptotene Option: C. Zygotene Option: D. Pachytene Primary oocytes are arrested in the diplotene stage of prophase I of meiosis I, therefore Option B, C and D are incorrect answers.

Table:

#MANTRA Steps of Oogenesis

questions.text: Which of the following is the 1st to be formed by the migration of the epiblast along the primitive streak?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Endoderm The movement of epiblast cells from the primitive streak and primitive node forms mesoderm and endoderm. The movement of epiblastic mesenchymal cells down the primitive streak is known as ingression.

Highyeild:

The first set of cells to move down the primitive streak integrate into the hypoblast layer and form endoderm, the first of the three germ layers.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Cardiac mesoderm Cardiac mesoderm is formed from the anterior splanchnic mesoderm, which is a region of the lateral plate mesoderm. The mesoderm layer forms after the endoderm layer during gastrulation, a process that occurs during the third week of human development. Option: C. Epidermis The epidermis, is the outermost layer of skin, develops from the embryonic ectoderm. The epidermis develops from the ectoderm through a multi-step process that involves signaling patterns and communication with the dermis. Option: D. Neural groove The neural groove is formed by the infolding of a thickened plate of ectoderm during embryonic development.

Extraedge:

Cells of the epiblast migrate toward the primitive streak. Upon arrival in the region of the streak, they become flask-shaped, detach from the epiblast, and slip beneath it. This inward movement is known as invagination. Once the cells have invaginated, some displace the hypoblast, creating the embryonic endoderm, and others come to lie between the epiblast and newly created endoderm to form mesoderm. Cells remaining in the epiblast then form ectoderm.

Table:

#MANTRA The epiblast, through the process of gastrulation, is the source of all of the germ layers, and cells in these layers will give rise to all of the tissues and organs in the embryo.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy underwent splenectomy for immune thrombocytopenic purpura. During the procedure, the surgeon noticed bleeding while separating the spleen from the stomach. Which vessel is most likely implicated in this bleeding?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Short gastric vessels During a splenectomy, the short gastric vessels and splenic capsule are most commonly injured, resulting in bleeding.

Highyeild:

The short gastric arteries are 5-7 small branches of the splenic artery that pass along part of the greater curvature of the stomach from left to right between the layers of the gastrolienal ligament, and are distributed to the greater curvature of the stomach.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Left gastric vessels The left gastric artery is the first and smallest branch of the celiac trunk which descends along the superior half of the lesser curvature of the stomach, anastomosing with the right gastric artery Option: C. gastroepiploic vessels The gastroepiploic arteries are located along the greater curvature of the stomach and supply blood to the stomach and greater omentum. Option: D. Splenic vessels The splenic artery runs along the superior and posterior margins of the pancreas, and then passes anterior to the left kidney and left suprarenal gland.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a derivative of neural crest cells?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Retinal pigment epithelium Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) is derived from the optic neuroepithelium, not neural crest.

Highyeild:

Neural Crest Derivatives ● Connective tissue and bones of the face and skull ● Cranial nerve ganglia ● C cells of the thyroid gland ● Conotruncal septum in the heart ● Odontoblasts ● Dermis in face and neck ● Spinal (dorsal root) ganglia ● Sympathetic chain and preaortic ganglia ● Parasympathetic ganglia of the gastrointestinal tract ● Adrenal medulla ● Schwann cells ● Glial cells ● Meninges (forebrain) ● Melanocytes ● Smooth muscle cells to blood vessels of the face and forebrain

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Ciliary muscles The ciliary muscles of the eye are derived from the neural crest. Option: C. Ciliary ganglion The ciliary ganglion is a parasympathetic ganglion in the head that originates from neural crest cells Option: D. Melanocytes Melanocytes in the body are derived from the neural crest (NC), a transient population of cells with stem cell properties that forms in the embryo.

questions.text: What mechanism is responsible for the release of secretions from the “A” marked gland?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Holocrine “A “ marked gland is sebaceous gland.

Highyeild:

Holocrine gland – secretory cells burst out pouring their contents, resulting in the death of the cells (complete loss of cytoplasm), e.g. sebaceous gland, tarsal gland.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Apocrine Apocrine gland – apical part of the cytoplasm of the secretory cells is lost in the process of secretion (partial loss of cytoplasm), e.g. lactating mammary gland, sweat gland in the axilla and external genitalia. Option: B. Merocrine Merocrine gland – secretory cells release their contents by exocytosis (no loss of cytoplasm), e.g. most of the compound glands. Option: C. Eccrine Eccrine glands are sweat glands that help regulate body temperature by releasing sweat onto the skin's surface.

Table:

#MANTRA Based on the mode of secretion: Merocrine gland – secretory cells release their contents by exocytosis (no loss of cytoplasm), e.g. most of the compound glands. Apocrine gland – apical part of the cytoplasm of the secretory cells is lost in the process of secretion (partial loss of cytoplasm), e.g. lactating mammary gland, sweat gland in the axilla and external genitalia. Holocrine gland – secretory cells burst out pouring their contents, resulting in the death of the cells (complete loss of cytoplasm), e.g. sebaceous gland, tarsal gland. Cytocrine gland – cells are released as secretion, e.g. testis (spermatozoa).

Solution:

Primitive streak The arrow marked structure is a primitive streak as shown in the image below.

Highyeild:

The primitive streak is a region of epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) where epiblast cells ingress to generate a new population of mesenchymal cells that give rise to mesoderm and definitive endoderm.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Notochord The notochord in humans is only present during the embryonic stages of development. The notochord develops into a vertebral column and provides a blueprint for the central nervous system to develop along with structural supports including the skeletal and muscular structures. Option: C. Neural groove The neural groove is a U-shaped groove that forms in the center of a developing embryo, and is a precursor to the central nervous system (CNS). Option: D. Secondary neural plate The secondary neural plate is a process that occurs during the development of the nervous system, where a solid cord of cells forms the neural tube.

Solution:

Intercalated discs The marked structure is an intercalated disc as shown in the cardiac muscle histological slide.

Highyeild:

Intercalated discs (ICDs) are cell-to-cell junctions in cardiac muscle that connect adjacent cardiomyocytes. Function- ICDs are essential for cellular function and regulation. They facilitate the arrangement of cells into organized layers, and ensure the fast propagation of electrical signals throughout the heart. ICDs also allow cardiomyocytes to withstand the mechanical forces of the beating heart.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Connective tissue Connective tissue is made up of three main components: Extracellular matrix : This is made up of an amorphous ground substance, extracellular fluid, and collagen and elastic fibers. The ground substance is a gelatinous material that surrounds the fibers. Cells : These include fibroblasts, macrophages, mast cells, and plasma cells Protein fibers : These include collagen, reticular, and elastic fibers Option: C. Cytoskeletal condensation In histology, the cytoskeleton is a complex network of protein filaments and associated proteins that provides structure, strength, and movement to a cell. Option: D. Nerve fibre In histology, nerve fibers, also known as axons, are thread-like extensions of nerve cells (neurons) that carry electrical impulses.

questions.text: The marked structure serves as a surface landmark for which anatomical structure?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Stem of lateral sulcus Marked structure is pterion, internally, the pterion is related to various anatomical structures, namely, the anterior division of the middle meningeal vessels, middle cerebral vessels, Sylvain fissure, circle of Willis, insula and Broca's motor speech area (on the left) and optic nerve.

Highyeild:

The pterion Surgical relationship The pterion is a surgical entry point for treating lesions in the anterior and middle cranial fossa. It provides access to the sylvian fissure, which leads to the circle of Willis aneurysms.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Pineal gland The pineal gland is located in the middle of the brain, in the epithalamus, where the two halves of the brain meet. Option: B. Wernicke's area Wernicke's area is located in the dominant hemisphere of the brain, in the posterior segment of the superior temporal gyrus. It's usually found on the left side of the brain, since 95% of people have a left dominant hemisphere. Option: D. Internal carotid artery siphon The carotid siphon is a tortuous, U- or S-shaped segment of the internal carotid artery (ICA) located in the base of the skull. It lies between the carotid canal and the T-junction, where the ICA splits into the middle cerebral artery (MCA) and the anterior cerebral artery (ACA).

Solution:

Oculomotor nerve The marked nerve is an oculomotor nerve as shown in the image below.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Abducens nerve At the tip of the petrous temporal bone, the abducens nerve leaves Dorello's canal and enters the cavernous sinus (a dural venous sinus). It travels through the cavernous sinus and enters the bony orbit via the superior orbital fissure. Option: C. Trochlear nerve The trochlear nerve passes through the superior orbital fissure of the sphenoid bone to reach the superior oblique muscle . Option: D. Ophthalmic division Ophthalmic nerve- Passes through the lateral portion of the cavernous sinus, then through the superior orbital fissure into the orbit. The ophthalmic nerve divides into three branches as it passes through or near the superior orbital fissure.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male recovering from facial nerve palsy complains of food getting stuck between the cheek and teeth while eating. What is the muscle affected in this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Buccinator The food getting stuck between the cheek and teeth while eating, is due to buccinator muscle.

Highyeild:

The buccinator muscle is a facial muscle that is responsible for compressing the cheeks and expelling air between the lips, such as in blowing a trumpet. It is also involved in mastication and holding food in the mouth while chewing. Its purpose is to pull back the angle of the mouth and to flatten the cheek area, which aids in holding the cheek to the teeth during chewing. This action causes the muscle to keep food pushed back on the occlusal surface of the posterior teeth, as when a person chews.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Levator labii superioris The levator labii superioris muscle elevates and everts the upper lip. This action is used when expressing some facial expressions Option: C. Zygomaticus major The zygomaticus major muscle, also known as the smiling muscle, is responsible for raising the upper lip and corners of the mouth to create facial expressions. Option: D. Orbicularis oris The orbicularis oris muscle contributes to the form and shape of the lips. Contraction of this muscle closes and protects the lips.
